title: miss america 2020 biochemist live science experiment
story: Donning a white lab coat, self-confessed “quirky scientist” Camille Schrier defeated  women competing for the Miss America title.The -year-old impressed celebrity judges, singer Kelly Rowland, ‘Queer Eye’ star Karamo Brown and ‘Superstore actress Lauren Ash, with a colourful chemistry demonstration of the catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide.She reportedly told the , that Miss America is someone who needs to educate.The Pennsylvanian native has two undergraduate degrees in biochemistry and systems biology, and told the crowd she also plans to get a doctor of pharmacy degree.In her acceptance speech, Ms Schrier said she hoped to break stereotypes about what it means to be a Miss America in ” by being a woman of science who is authentic to herself”.Ms Schrier said: “Im not the beauty queen. Im the brand ambassador for this organization and Im more than just someone with a crown on my head.”In her role as Miss America, Ms Schrier will spend a year advocating for Mind Your Meds, a drug safety and prevention programme.Ms Schriers victory is expected to be viewed as another progressive step away from Miss Americas traditional beauty contest format.Last year, the competition announced it was scrapping its highly criticized swimsuit competition.Candidates would instead participate in a series of interviews and talent demonstrations, allowing more time to advocate for their social impact initiatives and have their voices be heard.Ms Schrier addressed the changes to the Miss America competition on stage.She revealed she had tackled an eating disorder and only decided to compete for the crown after the swimsuit competition was ditched, along with other changes that have been made to modernize the organization.She said: “I kind of figured that I would never get on that stage because I was a woman who did not want to get into a swimsuit on stage.And I didn’t have a performing talent, which is really ironic now.”Ms Shrier is the first Miss America to win with a science experiment, a presentation she also demonstrates in schools.

title: grans home poo bombed pigeons neighbour
story: Kathy Waite says it has become a living hell as dozens of the birds descend on her home most days.The -year-old claims she hasnt had a good nights sleep over the neighbouring flock since the feeder was put up in .Mrs Waite, from Skegness, Lincs., said the pigeons s**t on every inch of her garden and that she has been sh*t on myself.She has confronted her neighbour and reported him to East Lyndsey District Council - who ordered him to stop feeding the birds for one month.Mum-of-six Kathy said: You can always hear them outside. And when theyre approaching its terrying because they get louder and louder like war bombers.I havent had a proper nights sleep in two years ever since we moved here.I feel completely helpless because for years nothing has been done. I feel under attack every day when they swoop in.Ive been s**t on myself a couple times, so now Im afraid to go out into the garden.Kathy, who works as a cleaner, said the extent of the damage was too much even for her to handle.It is legal to feed birds from a feeder in your garden.Howeverit starts to become a nuisance for neighbours or an issue of hygiene, the local council can get involved.As in this case the council can use powers under the Antisocial Behaviour Crime and Policing Act  in an attempt to reduce the extent of the feeding that is taking place.Andthe feeding is taking place in a council owned property, eviction can be used as a last resort. She said: Theyre causing all sorts of damage to my home, corroding the pipes, the roof. Its all rotten and disgusting, infested with their s**t.I had to put up a six foot fence up just to protect us from those pigeons, but theyre always covered in bird s**t.Ive had to repaint it twice, but theres no point really. Theyre relentless.Ive spent hundreds of pounds just fixing things around the house, in our garden, that theyve damaged.They have s**t on literally every last inch of my home.Kathy said her children are the ones who are suffering the most and avoid playing in the garden at all costs - despite investing £, into it.Her son Zak, , suffers with allergies but has seen his dosage of antihistamine double since moving to the new house - and he now finds himself needing an EpiPen.The Councils Environmental Health Manager, David Dodds, said: The problem with excessive bird feeding in this area of Skegness has led to high numbers of Pigeons congregating on roofs waiting for food to be distributed.This increase is now causing damage to buildings and property. We would ask members of the public not feed birds in this area of the town for the foreseeable future whilst we work to get the issue under control.We are not seeking to outlaw feeding of wild birds, particularly in the winter months, but where levels of feeding result in large flocks of the same type of bird this then becomes a problem.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mark carney bank of england governor salary where from
story: Who is he and who is taking over  Heres what we know.Mark Joseph Carney was born on March , , in Canada.He studied at Hard University where he graduated with high honours in Economics before completing his masters and doctoral degrees in the same field at St Peters College, Oxford.It would be the start of a long career in the world of finance after landing his first job in Goldman Sachs where he spent  years working at its offices in London, Tokyo, New York and Toronto.He left on a £million salary and was dubbed a rock star banker for his skill in keeping the economy growing in Canada when he was Governor of its national bank during the recession.Mr Carney took over as Governor of the Bank of England in July .He is the first non-Briton to be given the job since the Bank was created in .It followed a successful stint as Canadas central banker where he was praised for helping his country to avoid some of the worst effects of the  financial crisis.He agreed to take on the Bank of England post for five years with the option to continue for the full eight-year term, but instead opted to leave in  just as Britain officially leaves the EU.On December , it was announced Andrew Bailey would take over as the new Bank of England Governor.Mr Bailey, , will take over on March , , for eight years.During the EU referendum in  Mr Carney was slammed by some Brexit campaigners for saying that voting to leave the European Union would force the UK into a recession.Many believed this was a step too far for a Governor with a non-political remit.He defended his actions, saying: We have a responsibility to discharge our remit and we have a wider responsibility to the British people, who dont want risks kept from them.Following the UKs Brexit vote, the Bank slashed interest rates to . per cent.When questioned by MPs about how he handled the aftermath of the vote, Mr Carney said the historic low-cut of interest rates helped support house prices and the wider economy.He took a swipe at Prime Minister Theresa May by saying he refused to “take instruction” from politicians - after she said the rich had got richer while the poor had been squeezed.The latest accounts from the Bank of England shows that Mr Carney earned £, in .This includes a £, salary, £, in taxable benefits, and £,-a-week housing allowance.In the same time period, the British Prime Minister was paid a salary of £,.Bank of England Governors traditionally serve eight year terms but Mr Carney originally intended to serve only until January .That would have left him in the hot seat for just three months after Britain formally leaves the European Union in March, leaving a newcomer to navigate the aftermath of the orce.But he then extended his term until January o.Its believed Mr Carney refused to sign an eight-year contract because of his children’s education and that he had his eye on Canadian politics.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mad friday what when black eye
story: Extra security and police officers are often called on to deal with the crowds of drunk people, how will it go down this year Mad Friday is a nickname given to the last Friday before Christmas.It is the most popular night for office Christmas parties and for people eager to get out on the town, and this means it is often one of the busiest nights of the year for ambulance crews and police.Extra officers will be drafted in to deal with the expected chaos revellers will bring and pubs are also likely to put on extra security.Fights often break out as people indulge in a generous amount of booze.The last Friday before Christmas this year is December  - TODAY.The boozy day is likely to be the start of a weekend of fun, as many head out for festive celebrations.In December , Greater Manchester Police actually used the hashtag #MadMancFriday to expose some of the embarrassing acts revellers would do on the day.Pubs are likely to stick to the same opening times as on a normal Friday.However, it is advised to check with the pub or bar you are planning on visiting, to double checkthey are planning on doing anything special.Mobile units with medical help on standby will be a feature of many city centres.Ambulance crews and police officers will have been planning measures to deal with the night of carnage for weeks.It was originally known as Black Friday, but from  the press began to use the term Mad Friday.This was done to avoid confusion with the American Black Friday, when people all over the world get discounted products as retailers slash prices.In some parts of the UK the day has been referred to as Black Eye Friday.This name comes from the higher numbers of fights that break out in bars, clubs, and pubs.It can also be called Builders Friday, as it is the last day of work for many construction workers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: shortest day of the year winter solstice
story: But when exactly will it be in  and how many hours of daylight do we get The shortest day of  is Sunday, December .This is known as the winter solstice, marking the day of the year with the fewest sunlight hours.The word solstice literally means, in Latin, that the sun is standing still.Thats because it marks the point when the suns seasonal movement stops for a day, before it reverses and the amount of sunlight starts to change again.The sunrise across the UK will happen at around .am on Sunday, December .It will set at .pm, meaning there will be less than eight hours daylight.However, after that day the number of hours of daylight will increase each day.Although they both relate to a similar thing, there is a big dference between an equinox and a solstice.While a solstice represents either a longest or shortest day, the equinox falls on the days where day and night are the same .This happens twice a year, midway between the summer and winter solstices, on March  and September .These are referred to as the spring and fall equinox, marking the start of the seasons in the astrological calendar.The solstice always falls between December  and .Most years, it falls on the st in the UK, but sometimes it lands a little bit off-kilter, because it takes the Earth  and a quarter days to go around the sun.This extra quarter day is why we add a day to the calendar every four years with a leap year - to stop the dates drting gradually through the seasons.For the same reason, solstices and equinoxes are not always on the same day every year.December  marks our winter solstice, but its the summer solsticeyou head beneath the equator.In the southern hemisphere, the seasons are flipped compared to ours.That means December, January and February are the height of summer in countries like Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.So the December  solstice falls in the middle of their summer, while the June solstice is their winter. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chaotic diaries of headteachers weeks
story: NewsChaotic diaries of headteachers weeks expose shocking truth of crippling budget cutsEXCLUSIVE: Diaries of headteachers expose not only the lives of poverty striken children and families but the also the toll the pressures of underfunded school have on teachersShareCommentsByAmy Coles:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsIan Read typically works  hours a week " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTeachers are acting as social ­workers, family support workers, mental health practitioners, speech and language therapists, and even the police because of crippling cuts. Two headteachers shared a snapshot of a working week, giving an insight into how staff are being forced to pick up the pieces left by funding cuts of % per pupil since  and chronic staffing shortages. It paints a picture of staff under extreme pressure to provide an education and support to children in a system that, as one explains, is “fracturing and breaking”. In the Queen’s Speech yesterday Boris Johnson promised an increase in funding per pupil but it comes after nearly a decade of underfunding where real-terms spending has dropped by £.billion, from £.billion in   to £.billion. Unprecedented cuts to council funding has forced schools to slash support and funding for children with special needs and on Education, Health and Care Plans. There are , children with special needs who do not have a school place as support services are not there. ­Permanent exclusions have reached the highest point in nearly a decade after a rise in assaults, bullying, drugs and alcohol. Unions blame cuts to children’s services for making it harder to provide early intervention. One in three teachers have fed hungry children in class or bought them food, a YouGov poll found.Caretaker, builder, dinner lady, gardener, social worker, mental health practitioner, speech and language therapist, police officer, here two heads tell their stories: The diary of Ian Read, headteacher at Waterclfe Meadow Primary School, Sheffield  Monday Four staff phone in sick. They have the flu, which is also having a devastating effect on our attendance. It’s stressful as we just can’t afford supply teachers. We managed to get other staff to cover classes but it isn’t ideal. I think we’ve lost three staff as a result of the additional workload teachers have to put up with. I worry massively about the long-term implications of cuts and workload. If we carry on like this, staff will burn out and leave the profession. Tuesday I start with our weekly safeguarding meeting, where we talk about children getting some level of social care or support –  of our  pupils. After the meeting I pop into our Breakfast club. It has doubled in size since we opened it and today we feed almost  people – and often more. If we didn’t run it, kids would go hungry. A few years ago we used to help the occasional family access our local foodbank, now we are offering food parcels to families on a weekly basis. Then there’s the free sanitary towels we put in the toilets for parents and pupils who can’t afford them. Staff buy these and can’t keep up with demand. Wednesday I go on a home visit for a child who has been out of school for more than  months. They have been diagnosed with autism and attention deficit disorder, and live with a single parent and two siblings who have even more pronounced SEN issues. As they have been allocated a place with us we will do all we can for them. But I can’t afford more support staff. Do I take away a member of staff from the children with extra needs she currently supports, to give this new pupil the level of attention they are likely to need  Or do I hope the attention she can spare is enough  Thursday We still have three teachers and an assistant off sick and can’t cover the gaps ourselves any more. I have to spend what little money we do have on supply teachers. Without the efforts of staff, this week would’ve cost us more than £, in supply costs. Teachers have gone without breaks and taken additional work home as they were unable to do it in the day. I spoke to one teacher who has been ill all week and clearly should not be in school. But he knew the impact his absence would have on his class and on the other staff covering for him. Friday It’s nearly the weekend and I’ve worked more than  hours. It’s becoming typical. Looking around, I can see my staff are exhausted too. Today I found out that at least three teachers have bought laminators this year as the person who used to do most of this job in school was made redundant. They laminate school worksheets at home. Every day we do things that go beyond the traditional job of teaching to maintain standards while resources and capacity is cut. This pressure on staff is not sustainable. The diary of Diana Worthington, headteacher, Moorside Primary School, Halax, West Yorkshire  Monday Today I had to exclude a pupil for a physical assault on another pupil. It’s frustrating to admit this is increasingly a regular occurrence. Every time this happens it reminds me some of our most troubled pupils are being let down by the system. There is a lack of support for schools with mental health and family issues. We cannot put them on waiting lists, therefore we have to try managing the situation ourselves. It feels like we are not only educators but social workers, family support workers, mental health practitioners, speech and language therapists, sometimes even the police. Tuesday I went on a home visit to a family whose child has not come to school. Through home visits, I often see families living in extreme poverty. No carpets, bare walls, just mattresses on the floor. It can be shocking but it’s also really sad to see how families are being let down by public services who have no resources. At this time of year especially, many families’ monies are spent on heating and lighting their houses and then they apologise for their child having no dinner money or not being able to replace a unorm. While my school does everything it can to support these children, we cannot be expected to be experts in all these areas. Essentially we are fielding the funding cuts of all the other agencies – something that has to be put right. Wednesday We had a meeting to thank support staff for their hard work. Talk turned to the budget and I had to update them on the challenge the school faces. There is concern that after the next three years we will no longer be financially viable. We are looking at linking with other schools to pool resources. The staff askedredundancies were a possibility. It was a tough conversation to have.  Thursday It’s .am and I am dealing with a child who refuses to come to school. I spend  minutes talking to this child and their parent. The same reasons seem to come up a lot in these cases. I’ve seen children not wanting to come in over a fall-out with friends. More and more older children are falling out while playing online games in the evenings. By the next morning they don’t want to face school. I then spend the next half-hour trying to reintegrate them. I am spending more and more time trying to support pupils who should get help from public services. Friday I take the kids to the local museum. I may be the head but I have to drive the minibus. We only have a few minibus drivers as it is a signicant cost to train the staff. It’s no surprise we can’t afford a coach driver for the day. It’s always great to see how worthwhile these trips are. But as finances get tighter I worry they will have to be cut down and we may have to say goodbye to them altogether. It’s a sad thought. Do you know any inspiring teachers who have gone above and beyond to help their pupils  Email us at Mirrornews@mirror Kind staff spending own money on gts for kids  Teachers at a school so badly hit by Tory cuts that it has considered closing every other Friday are shelling out £ of their own money on food and gts for students. Royal Wootton Bassett Academy in Wiltshire, where % of pupils are classed as underprivileged, is overrun with requests from kids and parents on the breadline. Generous staff have given presents, food parcels, foodbank vouchers, Christmas trees and decorations. Headteacher George Croxford said: “We’ve had parents and kids welling up with tears when we’ve dropped off parcels. “It is an absolute tragedy this is going on all over the country. It is really dire and very hard for all concerned.” The academy, for pupils aged -, is struggling – staff numbers have shrunk by up to half in some departments and cuts mean it is losing its parent support adviser, who identies vulnerable children. The National Education Union estimates that by April , schools will have seen cuts of up to £ per pupil in the past five years. Mr Croxford added: “There is only so much you can cut.”  Hampers give a Christmas lesson in compassion A principal is helping to give more than  Christmas hampers to families in need. Matthew Tate raised over £, after launching an appeal to help the poorest in his community. The head at Hartsdown Academy, in Thanet, Kent, said: “We’re working in one of the most deprived areas of the country – with  school-age children homeless in our area. “We know parents who are choosing between food and heating this Christmas and aren’t able to give their kids what they want – despite working -hour shts. “I want people to know that they are loved and people care.” Teachers have spent their own cash on clothes and food at Abbey Hey Primary Academy, Gorton, Manchester, which even has a foodbank. At Tittensor First School in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffs, head Emily Proffitt told recently how she had to act as a caretaker, builder, dinner lady and gardener, and a head in Redcar, North Yorks, said he uses his salary to pay for school trips.Pressure and poor pay has contributed to the worst staffing crisis in decades, with nearly one in three teachers leaving the job within five years of qualying. Protest group Save our Schools said a boost of £.billion by -, announced by Prime Minister Johnson in the summer and starting in , would not even meet  levels. Analysis by unions shows more than % of schools will have less cash per pupil in real terms in  than in . Kate Taylor, of SOS, said teachers try to plug the gaps, adding: “Teachers are trying to provide this expertise, with no training, while working under immense pressure.”

title: labour must back out listen
story: NewsLabour must get back out there to listen, learn and support working peopleDaily Mirrors Ros Wynne Jones says anyone who thinks the Labour Party can carry on as it is with a simple change of personnel at the very top is as deluded, adding it must work to win back the trust of working peopleShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  DEC NewsLabour didn’t understand that its manesto was bewildering for people " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA painful week has passed since I was sat on a bench in a draughty town hall during the early dawn of a Tory majority ­government.If it was painful to watch the blue rosettes celebrate the narrow victory of Iain Duncan Smith at am, it’sbeen even more painful to watch the Queen read out the words of a racist, homophobic liar. And it’s been agonising to watch Prime Minister Johnson and Cummings quickly use Labour ’s Northern Fail to wield their power, tightening the knot on a hard Brexit , breaking their minimum wage pledge and moving against democratic ­industrial action.Yesterday, Tory MP Nadhim Zahawi was quick to tell us this was “a People’s Queen’s speech from a People’s Government”. This from a man who got the “People” to pay for heating his stables. Johnson’s majority is going to be brutal for the people Labour was formed to represent. Which is why there is no time for the party to wage war against itself. Never mind the rest of the country, it’s Labour that needs to find “more in common”.  Anyone who thinks the Labour Party can carry on as it is with a simple change of personnel at thevery top is as deluded as anyone who thinks Labour can drain the bathwater andto a halcyon past.For a start, we could stop being defined in our politics by the name of some male leader or other. Labour isn’t one bloke at the top of the party, but a dazzling, wonderful movement full of incredible women running tenants’ associations, pensioners running foodbanks, young people volunteering and the decent, solid men and women of the trade union movement. But it’s also true that for too long it’s been a party whose highest echelons have been talking down to people. It told them “we know what’s best for you” in the same tone in which it is now telling the country “we’re not so much angry as disappointed”. While Labour went on waving its credentials as a democratic party like a £ note at a crowded bar, it ignored the fact its base had stopped going to the pub. When I once raised this with a party official, I was told that “people don’t know what they want because they are in hoc to a fascist media”.  That lack of humility meant Labour didn’t understand that its manesto – and it was a bold, brave manesto – was bewildering for people. When you’re hanging on by your fingernails on a mountainside, you don’t want an avalanche, you want a rope.Added to a position on Brexit that looked two-faced, the damage to Labour’s moral authority caused by a failure to stamp out anti-Semitism, and a deep war waged over four years against Jeremy Corbyn , the “red wall” came apart like Lego.Of course, the media and the money are stacked against the Labour Party. Labour wants to redistribute power. And the dirty tricks by Cummings and his acolytes were vicious and cunning. We mustn’t expect this to be a fair fight. During this period of rebuilding the party, Labour needs to go back to being judged by its actions, running soup kitchens and foodbanks, organising tenants, taking on community projects defined by the community. It should take up Alex Sobel MP’s suggestion that every closed Labour MP’s office should become an advice centre.  Labour’s Community Organising Unit did make a dference. Despite only having resources to operate in  of Labour’s key seats, it ­contributed towards some of the greatest glimmers of hope, including the Labour wins in Putney and Sheffield Hallam. Some sneer at Labour’s only gain being in metropolitan Putney, but it was the working class turnout from estates in Roehampton that turned the seat red. Analysis done by the Community Organising Unit shows the swing away from Labour was % less in seats where they were deployed. In Yorkshire, a key “red wall” ­battleground, the swing dropped from % to %. These were tough seats to fight for, yet they held up better.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson has unveiled the most radical Queenaposs Speech in a generation with measures to toughen up criminal justice, invest in the NHS and deliver on the peopleaposs priorities. The Prime Minister trumped Bills which will ensure the most serious violent offenders - including terrorists - serve longer prison terms after the London Bridge attack. A Royal Commission will be established to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the criminal justice process, and the Government will enshrine in law a commitment on NHS funding. Addressing MPs after the speech, Mr Johnson vowed that his Government would work flat out to deliver a new golden age for the UK, as he insisted his vision is for the long term. This is not a programme for one year or one parliament - it is a blueprint for the future of Britain, he said. But TUC general secretary Frances O’Grady sounded a note of caution - saying working people will want to check the small print before trusting this government’s promises. So what are the details in the small print  Weaposve had a look at  points you should know. Boris Johnson was been accused of rowing back on his promise to implement a £. minimum wage by  for everyone over the age of .It was the flagship policy announcement at the Tory conference, where Chancellor Sajid Javid proclaimed it would show the Tories are the workersapos party and help million workers.It is to be achieved by pegging the wage to two-thirds of median earnings, not % as it is now. But the small print of the Queenaposs Speech shows there is a sneaky get-out clause. It says the change to two-thirds of median earnings will only happen provided economic conditions allow. That is likely to prompt speculation thatthere is an economic downturn, the rise wonapost happen.Chi Onwurah, shadow business minister, told HuffPost UK: “In the very first moments of his new government Boris Johnson is already breaking promises he made during the election.. A shake-up of the entire constitution  The Queenaposs Speech plans a massive overhaul of Britainaposs constitution just a week after winning power. The Prime Minister announced that he would set up a new commission which could radically alter how Britain works. He will use the excuse of restoring trust in politics - even though he was widely considering to have undermined it during his time at No  so far. In the small print, the Commission promises to examine the broader aspects of the constitution in depth and develop proposals to restore trust in our institutions and in how our democracy operates. But the changes could prompt immediate fears that the Tory government was attempting to bolster its own power. The new unit could redraw constituency boundaries to reduce the number of MPs from  to , a move which could favour the Conservatives. He could also repeal the Fixed Term Parliaments Act meaning he could call an election when he wants to. There could be a move to repeal the Human Rights Act, replacing it with a bill of rights that could potentially lower protections. And in the wake of Mr Johnsonaposs Supreme Court loss, Britainaposs most senior judges could be made more accountable to Parliament - which could undermine the independence of the judiciary. Best for Britain chief executive Naomi Smith said: Johnsonaposs proposed constitution, democracy and rights commission should set alarm bells ringing for anyone who believes that Parliament must be able to act as a brake on a runaway government. We must be hyper-vigilant to any chipping away of the checks-and-balances that keep our democracy ing. No later flatly denied Supreme Court judges could become political appointees. . Britain could get new laws on treason  The small print of a law on espionage says the government will look at the case for updating treason laws. There is no further detail but it raises the spectre of new offences being allowed under laws that date back to Medieval times. MPs including Tory Tom Tugendhat and Labouraposs Khalid Mahmood have previously argued there is a case for updating the  Treason Act. Itaposs true that itaposs out of date. The last person to be tried for treason in the UK was in . But the Law Commission previously said treason law had ceased to be of contemporary relevance. And reviving it may prompt fears of a law that was killed off long ago coming back into being. . Workersapos rights pledges just arenapost clear yet Thereaposs a new Employment Bill which the Tories say will safeguard workersapos rights after Brexit .But the thing is, there isnapost enough detail on it yet to be clear about what those safeguards will be. The original Brexit Bill in October had promised that each time ministers make a new law in future, they would have to commit that in their view it doesnapost regress from EU workersapos rights. If they could not do so, they would have had to make a statement saying the new law might regress from EU workersapos rights. Thataposs now been dropped from the Brexit Bill. But it doesnapost yet, according to the Queenaposs Speech notes, appear in the new Employment Bill. Instead, the Queenaposs Speech makes a more general statement that the new Bill will protect and enhance workersapos rights as the UK leaves the EU, making Britain the best place in the world to work. Tim Roache, GMB General Secretary, said: “The Prime Minister claims he will protect and enhance workers’ rights but his record on keeping his promises leaves a lot to be desired. We’ll be holding him to account.  . People will be forced to show ID to vote   The Queenaposs Speech confirms measures will be implemented to force voters to show photo ID before being allowed to vote. Hundreds of people were denied their right to vote in last year’s local elections after ministers forced through a pilot scheme, despite warnings it could disenfranchise older voters and people from minority groups. The trial, which was held in eight council areas, resulted in  people being turned away. That was despite official figures showing there were just eight allegations of people lying about who they are at a polling station - known as personation - in . That was down from  in ,  in ,  in  and  in , the Electoral Commission figures show. The Queenaposs Speech says people without an approved form of photographic ID will be able to request an identity document. But campaigners say the move will hit low-income and vulnerable voters less likely to have the right paperwork. There are other measures too that critics say could benefit the Tories - letting ex-pats vote for leand shaking up constituency boundaries. . Thereaposs still no solution for social care The Queenaposs Speech promises to begin urgent work on a cross-party solution to social care. But despite Boris Johnson saying he had a plan ready to go, there is no detail - apart from a commitment that no one will have to sell their home.Dan Scorer of the learning disability charity Mencap said: Cross party consensus is a good idea, but they need to get on with it. The extra £ billion sounds a lot, but is nowhere near enough Dr Jenner Dixon chief executive of the Health Foundation said: With growing numbers of people unable to access the care they need, there is no time to waste. Fundamental reform of social care should be the immediate priority - the government must now grasp the nettle. Jeremy Hughes, Chief Executive at Alzheimer’s Society, said “The state of dementia care is in crisis. The Prime Minister committed to end the injustice when he met Barbara Windsor. Where’s the action  Jonathan Blades of the MS Society said: “It’s been years since we were first promised a plan on how to fix our failing social care system, and we’re still in the dark.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s a bit of a shame Andrew Lloyd Webber quit the House of Lords a couple of years back, because today’s Queen’s Speech would have made a brilliant advert for Cats. The House of Lords, after all, is made up of hundreds of grey, uncanny faces, draped in acres of fur, waiting and praying to be transported swtly to the afterle. And just like Tom Hooper’s new movie - Boris Johnson’s second Queen’s Speech was pure nightmare fuel. Little can prepare you for how preposterous the pomp of the State Opening of Parliament truly is.Liz may have enjoyed a dress-down day, this being her second outing of the year - the logos on TV screens around the Lords have been crafted to point out we’re watching “State Opening Of Parliament: December .”But that’s not to say the whole day was a scruffy affair. Presumably the irony of reading out the priorities of the ‘People’s Government’, while a young woman carries your oversized, magic, velvet santa hat on its own little stick, is not lost on Her Maj - who incidentally, seems to have a snfly cold. The great, good and political stuffing of the House of Lords filed dutully through the Moses Room to have their ermine robes hiked on their shoulders and brushed down. Most peers rent their red glad rags from a company - like graduation robes. But the real House of Lords lers buy their own gowns and - I’m told - pay for them to be stored somewhere until needed. Like a horse.  And take this, for example - which we assure you is from the day’s itinerary and not from a Dungeons and Dragons rulebook. “As soon as Her Majesty has departed, the Crown, the Cap of Maintenance and the Sword of State are carried under escort to the Sovereign’s Entrance. The Gentlemen at Arms, having handed in their axes, proceed to the Sovereign’s Entrance, followed by the Yeomen of the Guard. “The Household Cavalry close and dismiss.” Boris Johnson too was on feline form this morning, although his grinning cat face was more Cheshire than Jellicle. Try as he might, he couldn’t engage grumpy Jeremy Corbyn in conversation, the lame-duck Labour leader looking distressingly like he might be choking on a hairball on their amble over from the Commons.  Behind them, a sharp-elbowed Emily Thornberry was engaging in an eye-catchingly animated conversation with the SNP’s Ian Blackford. Perhaps she was asking him about Nicola Sturgeon’s demands for another independence referendum. Perhaps she was asking him whether he’d seen the new Star Wars yet. Either way, Blackford didn’t seem nearly as interested in having his face on every TV news broadcast for the rest of the day as Thornberry. Back in the Lords, peers and assorted dignitaries watched with feint disdain as the Commons rabble piled in. Someone eventually had to shush them so the Queen could get on with her big solo performance.  Unusually for such a major constitutional event, there was a larger than usual amount of space available on the red benches. Newly installed Lord Mann of the Peoplewas in attendance, looking set to pounce on arch-foe Jeremy Corbynhe so much as raised an eyebrow. Met Commissioner Cressida Dick was up in the cheap seats, primed to pounce on Lord Mannhe pounced on Jeremy. And badge-wearing Supreme Court legend Lady Hale was down the front, presumably delighted that the very future of British democracy is no longer something she personally has to worry about any more. Peers are usually only too happy to clock in for their £ allowance, to get a bit of warm, a nice lunch and a snooze on the big red sofas.

The agenda includes some policies that will be welcomed by Mirror readers, including scrapping hospital car parking charges for those in greatest need, a ban on trophy hunting and help for our struggling high streets. There will also be extra money for the NHS, the police and education. While this funding is important it fails to compensate for nine years of Tory cuts and is less than Labour planned to spend had it won the election. Having spent years playing Scrooge, the Conservatives deserve no credit for belatedly handing out a few Christmas gts. There are also worrying proposals to neuter the unions and curb the independence of the judiciary. Johnson has form when it comes to making extravagant claims then reneging on them. title: christmas never same without mum
story: NewsChristmas will never be the same without mum - but well celebrate for her this yearMatthew Scotts mum Sharon loved everything about Christmas and he remembers her dancing in the kitchen singing her favourite festive songs at the top of her voiceShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  DEC NewsMatthew with his mum Sharon at her favourite time of the year" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf youaposre lucky enough to have the people you love most in the world around you, Christmas is a time of happiness and joy. But for people dealing with grief, the festivities often bring a new wave of pain and heartbreak. TV producer Matthew Scott lost his mum Sharon  months ago and was dreading his first Christmas without her last year. He made excuses when friends asked him out for drinks, wiped the Christmas songs from his playlists and said the day itself just felt wrong. But this year things are going to be dferent. While the Scott family accept that Christmas will never be the same, they know how much their mum loved the festivities. So this year, theyaposre going to celebrate - because itaposs what she would have wanted. Here, Matthew explains what itaposs really like to deal with unimaginable grief at this time of year. --- Every year until last Christmas, a parcel would arrive for me on November th, A-sized and rather thin. The advent calendar, sent from mum without fail. But now I buy my own. A reminder of being without my mother aged . It’s been  months this December since mum passed away from secondary breast cancer. She was . For many, Christmas is the most wonderful time of the year. Music fills the air, it’s a time meant for joyous celebration with friends and family. But for me it’s also the season for intensied grief. And I’m not alone. Cruse Bereavement care saw a % increase in December helpline calls compared to  while , Samaritans volunteers responded to an average of  calls for help each from people feeling overwhelmed on th December. Mum loved Christmas. It was at Christmas that she excelled herself. She brought the family together. For the last few years of her le, I’d count down the days until I’d speed along the M from London back to rural Herefordshire, playing Chris Rea’s Driving Home for Christmas.  I’d arrive to boxes and boxes of chocolates that mum claimed were untouchable because they were “for Christmas Day”. And yet we were still eating them in January. Mum would get me up at the crack of dawn and shout “wakey wakey, it’s Christmaaaaas!. Even in our s, my sister and I would wait at the top of the stairs while mum would “checkSanta’s been” before we could come down. It wasn’t Christmas without her gravy with a secret spoonful of cranberry sauce for sweetness, stirred to the beat of Michael Bublé. She would dance around the kitchen, singing at the top of her voice while the dog would go mad. Mum was the most selfless woman. I remember we once met an old man in a café who lived alone. Mum got chatting and wanted to invite him round on Christmas day.  When she got her five-year all clear from cancer the first time around, she told me how she felt a new lease of le. How every flower seemed brighter, like she was living le in HD. Mum knew that le was precious. I was  when she passed in July last year. She got ill again very quickly and from her diagnosis to her death it was just six weeks.  My sister and I slept by her side in Cheltenham hospital every night during the final weeks. With things deteriorating rapidly, the three of us moved to a local hospice. From then on, time felt irrelevant. In a strange way, those last few days were the most therapeutic. It was just us, no distractions, no doctors reporting results every four hours. I remember singing to her in bed as she slowly smiled, eyes shut. The feeling of not wanting to waste a moment together tiptoes on the edge of never knowing when the final moment will come. But it did. I think about her death every day. Navigating the world since then has felt like I’m in a trance. I used to phone mum every day on my walk home from work. Sometimes we’d just stay on the phone together, not saying much. For a while I still called her number. At first, losing her felt like the end of my s. It aged me. Responsibility for my sister, my nan, and our dog Archie fell to me. I am estranged from my father, but mum and I were incredibly close. The paperwork that comes with someone passing is always overwhelming but aged , combined with losing someone who was my main support system, it was excruciating.  Just when you think you are coping well, a season or anniversary approaches and the memories take you right back to where you started. Last Christmas, the first one without my mum, my coping mechanism was to ignore the festive spirit. I made excuses to friends when asked to meet up for a mulled wine and Mariah Carey was removed from Spoty. On the day itself, my sister and I woke up in the family home and the rooms felt cold and empty. We laid a wreath on mum’s grave on Christmas morning and stopped quietly for a short while. We didn’t say much all day. Lunch was at my auntie’s but the atmosphere, the food and the exchanging of presents all felt wrong. It just wasn’t Christmas. But this year will be dferent. Mum loved Christmas and she would want us to fall back in love with it. So we will. We will get out her favourite baubles that she carefully bubble-wrapped, we will iron the Christmas tablecloth, white with embroidered holly leaves, and we will make her gravy.  My sister, a -year-old NHS nurse who cared for my mum devotedly, has to work on Christmas day so we’ll make merry a day late on Boxing Day. We’ve invited our nan and we’ll lay a place for mum and grandad, who we also lost months after mum. We can’t forget they aren’t here, so we will include them. I am by no means finished with grief. My mind runs wild with regret, missed opportunities, things I wish we’d done or said together. Grief is unfixable. It doesn’t heal.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Harry Potter fan is set for a truly magical Christmas after finally being gted a new heart. Dom Davies was born with a congenital defect in his right ventricle and needed surgery at four days old, then again aged three and seven. At this time last year, the -year-old was so poorly he was struggling to breathe and could not eat or finish a sentence without gasping for air. But now, he is paying tribute to the donor who has made his dream of having a new heart come true – and looking forward to “properly celebrating Christmas with a bellyful of turkey”. Dom said: I didn’t think I would live to see another Christmas. I was going by the fact I’d had  years and that would be it. Last Christmas, I could not dream of getting a new heart. But I hoped against hope. He also told of how Harry Potter’s adventures had helped him come to terms with the concept of death during his agonising wait for a donor. Dom was introduced to author JK Rowling’s boy wizard by his dad, who read him bedtime stories.  He said: My love of Harry Potter helped me come to terms with death, so I didn’t see it as a bad, scary thing, just something I had to accept. But I still didn’t want to think about it. And he added of his transplant: “[I thought] either it will go fine and I will bewell or it won’t and I won’t know anything about it.” Dom went on the list for a new heart in October  and finally got his op at Newcastle Freeman Hospital earlier this year. He said: “The first thing I said to Mum was, ‘I can breathe’.” Older brother Benie, , an aspiring musician, wrote a song to keep Dom’s spirits up and told of his moments with him before the operation – during which his brother said farewell to his loved ones, in case he did not survive. Benie said: “I gave him a salute, I did not want him to think it was a final goodbye.” Dom, from Suffolk, is now fronting the British Heart Foundation’s Christmas campaign. It will support the Mirror-backed Max and Keira’s Law on organ donation – the opt-out system that comes into force in spring .  Dom backed our four-year Change the Law for Le campaign and appeared on TV as the new legislation passed through Parliament, explaining that a donor would save his le. He even met Max at the Freeman, saying: “I saw Max at one point after my surgery, which was strange since I’d seen him in the news while I was waiting.

Paul Harrison, , roped his we Samantha, , into the illegal enterprise, which they ran from their home, splashing out on a holiday, new car and personalised number plate. Suspicions were raised when a large batch of envelopes was rejected at a sorting office, with tests showing phosphor had been completely washed off the stamps. Investigators then raided the coupleaposs Barnsley home and found stamps being sorted and towels to dry them as well as related products all over the address.  Friend Graham Rought, a former dental technician from Birmingham, was also involved, carrying out the washing process from his garden shed. Ben Close, prosecuting at Birmingham Crown Court, said the offence involved obtaining and selling large quantities of stamps which had already been through the postage system. They bought second hand stamps, removed from envelopes, and sold them on so they could be reused. Paul Harrison accepts he put them on grease proof paper to make them appear asnew. Rought was involved in washing off the franking marks. The latter had been part of the scam for two and a half years with Harrison having operated an account called Affordable Stamps since June . Harrison, of Barnsley, purchased stamps in kiloware and sold them on Amazon and eBay, avoiding details being recorded on invoices in his dealings with others. He was locked up for four years after being convicted of adapting, supplying and possessing articles for fraud. He also admitted to money laundering and another charge of supplying articles for fraud.  His we, of the same address, was convicted of money laundering and sentenced to two years, suspended for two years. She was ordered to do  hours unpaid work. Rought, of Tile Cross, admitted adapting, supplying and possessing articles for fraud and money laundering. He was handed an  month sentence, suspended for  months, and ordered to do  hours unpaid work.  Mr Close said an investigation was launched after a large quantity of envelopes were rejected in Glasgow at on February , . They were largely addressed to schools in Scotland, and traced back to the Harrisons, with the process going on at their home when it was raided. The prosecutor said Harrison had contacted Rought on a number of occasions asking him about the method he used to wash the stamps.  There were some flirtatious exchanges between them because Rought thought he was speaking to Samantha Harrison, Mr Close said. The court heard Paul Harrison had been involved in the sale of around , stamps which had resulted in loss to Royal Mail of £,. Just over £, had gone into an account held by the Harrisons while Roughtaposs benefit had amounted to around £, and he had caused a loss to the Royal Mail of £,.  Paul Harrison had recruited his we into the scam, the court heard. In passing sentence Recorder Naomi Ellenbogen QC told Paul Harrison: It is clear to me this was a calculated business activity, the proceeds of which were your prime income. The fraud took place over a period of just short of nine years. You made considerable gain from these offences. James Bruce, for Rought, said he was arrested in August  and that the matter had been hanging over his head since that time.  He said it was not a sophisticated endeavour and that he had carried out the washing process in his garden shed. This was a one man band. He did not employ anyone , he added.

Iaposm absolutely devastated, mentally and financially, that Iaposve not been given the opportunity to resit the assignment that Iaposm entitled to. Itaposs a really hard , word essay that was set for us to complete whilst we were on a seven-week placement and now because I failed it, Iaposve been told that Iaposll have to wait until January  to re-join the course, which I donapost want to do. The country is crying out for nurses and yet this is how Iaposve been treated. My future career has been ruined and thereaposs been absolutely no compassion, despite having compassion drilled into us as future nurses.  I feel like Iaposve been left out to dry and now have no finances coming in - itaposs absolutely appalling. Iaposm a single parent with four kids aged five, eight,  and  and my only income was my student finance. She also says that she has incurred expense travelling to her placements over the last two years, as well as paying for parking costs and working for free - money that she will also be unable to recoup. But despite appealing the decision made by the university, the educational establishment has stuck firm with their decision. The young family, living in Wythenshawe, Manchester, who had outwardly had seemed to have the world at their feet, was completely destroyed. What started as a whirlwind romance ended with a two-year-old boy dead, his mother jailed for  years for his manslaughter, and his father, Peter Chilvers, yesterday jailed for  months for the domestic abuse which triggered her breakdown.  A court has now heard how Lesicka was subjected to a relentless psychological abuse by Chilvers, a Ryanair pilot.She felt trapped her in a toxic relationship where his cruel, degrading torment drove her to desperation, reports the Manchester Evening News. Chilvers had inflicted a campaign of cruelty against Lesicka, forcing her into degrading sexual acts and into eating hairs he plucked from his head, while he had an affair with another flight attendant, who is mother to his two young daughters. A aposcontrolling monsterapos aposMagdaapos, as she was known to friends, had been a confident young air stewardess when she first met Chilvers, an ambitious young pilot, in . The pair had fallen for each other at their work Christmas party in Germany, when both were working for Ryanair.  After he attended her th birthday party, they chatted on Facebook and slept together for the first time. Soon flight attendant Lesicka and Chilvers were wrapped up love and the lestyle of travel that came with their jobs. Within weeks they had moved in together, and it wasnapost long before Chilvers, the son of retired teachers, soon began to show a bullying side to his character. The first sign came after a drunken night out. Chilvers had vomited everywhere so Lesicka slept on the sofa, to avoid getting any sick on her. When he woke up, Chilvers accused her of not loving him, shouted at her, slammed the doors and banged on a wall. Lesicka ended up apologising to him. It was, prosecutors would later say after their relationship had unravelled with such horrendous consequences, an early indication of the behaviour Chilvers would use to aposintimidate and controlapos Lesicka. He would become, in her words, aposa controlling monsterapos.  It had meant everything to Peter Chilvers to become a pilot. His family had made huge sacrices to help him achieve his dream. As he put it, aposthey all really believed in me and I wanted to succeed in leapos. His parents re-mortgaged their home to help pay the £, it cost to qualy, and his grandmother lent him some of her le savings. Chilvers, originally from Stoke-on-Trent, had first become interested in flying as a teenager who was into gliding. He went on to study modern history and international relations at university, and during his studies the advice of a family friend made him set on becoming a pilot. By January  he and Magdalena Lesicka were aposhead over heels in loveapos.  But when they moved to the UK, Lesicka began to feel more isolated, being further away from her family in her native Poland. She had got a staff transfer after Chilvers moved to Liverpool for work, moving in with him to a caravan in Frodsham, Cheshire, and then a nearby rental cottage, as they embarked on a new le together. But, as time wore on, Chilvers behaviour towards his partner got worse and worse. Prosecutors would later tell how he aposrepeatedly mistreated and bullied her at ever increasing levels to see what he could get away withapos. There was irrational jealousy, picking fights, accusing her of being apostoo friendlyapos with other men when they went out. There was casual sadism, like pinching her - or suddenly holding her nose and mouth, as they kissed, so she couldnapost breathe, only releasing his grip as she squirmed in distress. And there were his rages, with Chilvers backing Lesicka into a corner, banging the wall above her head with his fist as she cowered. He would blame her for these things - or deny anything had happened. Peter Chilvers treated Magda Lesicka asshe was a possession to do with as he pleased, Rob Hall, the prosecutor in his trial said.  A troubled engagement Despite all this, both seemed set on further committment. One day Chilvers took Lesicka to a beauty spot beside Coniston Water, a favourite destination of his family growing up. After a walk there, Chilvers decided to apospop the questionapos, but the moment was killed, according to him, when she said, aposI hope you are not going to propose to meapos. Nonetheless, on February , , a leap year, the day traditionally women propose to men, Lesicka decided to propose to him - hoping marriage would improve things between them. Chilvers accepted, but did not tell his family of the proposal for nine months, something that made her feel like she wasnapost good enough for him. They bought custom made rings from a jewellers in Krakow. But they would never marry. After finding the proposal had not improved their relationship, Lesicka decided to apply for another job. She moved to Dubai, with Chilvers insisting that she only stay for six months. They met up around the world when they could, and jurors heard that the long-distance relationship seemed to suit them better. But when Lesicka ed, they moved to Stoke and Chilversapos controlling behaviour continued.  In  Lesicka got a new job, working for Cross Country Trains, based at Piccadilly station in Manchester. Their relationship was still a dficult one, made worse by Chilversapos affair with his collague. Lesicka found out, and she broke up with him. What she didnapost realise at that time was that she had fallen pregnant with Chilversapos child. Chilvers was angered by the news and demanded that Lesicka have an abortion. On the phone from a holiday in New Zealand with his parents, Chilvers said having a baby would aposruin his career and leapos. In messages, he called Lesicka a aposmonsterapos, a aposbitchapos and a aposselfish c**tapos for wanting to have the baby. The response from Peter Chilvers was to send her a draft legal contract that outlined their responsibilitiesMagda Lesicka kept the baby, prosecutor Rob Hall later told Chilversapos trial. In April , Lesicka again discovered Chilvers was having an affair - with a female member of Ryanair cabin crew. Chilvers was promoted to Captain with the airline and he moved to Lanzarote for work. He showed, prosecutors would claim, aposlittle interest in the pregnancyapos. Cruel bully called fiancee a apossheepapos  James was born in September , and mother and son joined Chilvers in Lanzarote. But soon after that, Chilvers began to tell Lesicka that having the baby had taken his freedom away, and that he felt aposbetrayedapos and aposdisgustedapos with her. Magda Lesicka would do anything for James, including seeking to create a happy home le for him, eventhat meant accommodating Peter Chilvers’s attacks on her personality and decision-making, Mr Hall said. Chilvers throttled Lesicka a number of times. He regularly subjected her to degrading acts, to which she felt she had no choice but to consent. He would pull out hairs from his head and put them in her mouth, before ordering her to aposswallowapos. And he aposmentally demeanedapos her, calling her a apossheepapos and describing himself as a apossheep ownerapos. But when Lesicka suggested that she and James shouldto the UK from Lanzarote, Chilvers told her: If you ever try and run away and hide, I will find you and will kill you.  Hethreatened her thatthe issue of who James should live with after they separated ever went to court, he would have more money than her, he would get better lawyers than her and he would make sure that she never saw James again, Rob Hall told Chilvers trial. In July , the young family moved to Wythenshawe, on a new-build estate close to Manchester Airport. By , Chilvers work base had become Liverpool Airport, so he regularly stayed in Wythenshawe with them, all the while continuing his affair. Later that year, Chilvers bought a home in Cheshire to aposlead a le awayapos from Lesicka, but problems continued. On the occasions when Magda Lesicka summoned up enough courage to talk to Peter Chilvers about the state of their relationship and her desire to end their relationship, he would manipulate her into carrying on, Mr Hall said. At one point in the car, Lesicka dared to confront Chilvers, telling him: You don’t love me. You don’t love James. You just love yourself.  Around that time, Lesicka started to confide with her colleagues about the abuse she suffered, and showed them bruises she suffered at Chilversapos hand. By August  their relationship was in pieces. In the week before Jamesapos death Chilvers went to solicitors to draw up a aposcohabitation contractapos, which stated Lesicka would have to pay £ a month to live with him, and she wouldnapost have any claim to the ownership of the house. He assaulted Lesicka in front of James after losing his temper, pushing her to the floor and sitting on her chest, before tickling her asit was a game. When Lesicka heard that the woman Chilvers had been having an affair with was moving to work from Manchester Airport, Chilvers became angry and threw her phone to the floor, smashing the screen. The lead-up to the tragedy In the days before he died, James went to stay with Chilversapos parents in the Lake District. Lesicka used the time to start making plans for a new le away from Chilvers. She researched rental properties, started to make notes about the abuse she had suffered, took pictures of her bruises, and told her manager at work of what was happening in her relationship. She also went to the police.  Officers planned to arrest Chilvers when he arrived back in Wythenshawe after flying a Ryanair service to Tenere. But when they told Lesicka of their plan, she was fearful of what would happen and begged officers to just log her complaint, rather than carry out the arrest. Chilvers would have been arrested on the day Lesicka went on to kill James. He was due to arrive back at Manchester Airport at .pm on August . As he was landing, Lesicka suffered a apossuddenapos mental breakdown. She stabbed their son to death in an upstairs bedroom at the house on Beaford Road and then tried to commit suicide. When Chilvers arrived back at Beaford Road at .pm, Lesicka fell into his arms, seriously injured.  He took her to hospital, unaware that James was fatally injured. It was only at the hospital that a concern was raised for the young boy. Police arrived at the house at about .am, and found the toddler dead. aposEgocentricapos pilot who blamed everyone but himself Officers were only able to speak to Lesicka about Jamesapos death two and a half months later, as she had originally been detained under the Mental Health Act. Later doctors agreed that Lesicka was suffering from aposan abnormality of mental ing which impaired her ability to understand her own conduct, form a rational judgement or exercise self-controlapos. On those grounds, Lesicka, who had not previously suffered from mental health problems, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. On Facebook in September, Chilvers posted a series of pictures of his son, writing: Jamie, my beautul and wonderful darling. You would have been  today. We all miss you desperately. Two years since your murder and still nothing has been done. On this day, your birthday, I solemnly promise you that I will fight for justice for you darling. I will always love you and always think of you. aposAlways alwaysapos Daddy. But in the sentencing hearing this week, Judge Patrick Field QC told Chilvers he had treated Lesicka as his apospropertyapos.  I have detected no more than a hint of your remorse and I note that even a doctor describes you as egocentric, having a longing for appreciation, and a reduced ability to understand fully how your behaviour affects others, and that you seek to minimise what you have done wrong and seek to sht the blame to others, the judge told him. You apparently have a preoccupation with the injustice of it all. That attitude was on full public display when you gave evidence. Chilvers now has two other children with the cabin crew worker he was having an affair with. His barrister Mark Ford said that relationship shows a dferent side to the defendant, as it is apossupportiveapos, aposco-operativeapos and aposlovingapos.  Chilvers, the defence lawyer said, is aposdeeply traumatisedapos by the death of his son, frequently breaking into aposhysterical screamingapos. It is frankly impossible for anybody to comprehend the ordeal that Mr Chilvers and his family have undergone, Mr Ford said. He is, in short, a man on the edge, and he has been for over two years. The barrister appealed to the judge for Chilvers to be spared jail, because he has no previous convictions and is the aposprimary carerapos of his two children. But Judge Field said he had concluded aposwithout hesitationapos that only prison was justied. As Mr Ford put it, just a few years ago, Chilvers had the aposworld at his feetapos. Now he has lost his job, his freedom, and his young son. aposHe has taken everything from meapos As for Lesicka, in a statement from her jail cell, she described herself as feeling aposugly, worthless, defenceless, ashamed and guiltyapos. I have very little left in my le, she said. Her words were read to the court this week, giving her a voice for the first time as she gave evidence for the prosecution during Chilversaposs Manchester Crown Court trial for abusing her, and prepared a victim impact statement to be read on her behalf at his sentencing In the statement, Lesicka said: Itaposs hard to see myself as a victim given the tragic outcome. I know my le has been changed forever and there is nothing I can do change it back. I have the rest of my le to contemplate these events and it is a daunting prospect. When I started a relationship with Peter Chilvers I had absolutely no idea he would be the controlling monster I discovered him to be. It is important that the public understand what Peter Chilversaposs abuse did to me. It destroyed me. I have no idea how he achieved this and I will probably spend the rest of my le trying to work out how he turned the confident, ambitious me into what I am now. He broke me and I find it almost impossible to contemplate that I let this happen. Living with Peter became an exercise of walking on eggshells. The best way to describe the latter stages of the relationship is it became a power struggle. I tried to leave but he would not let me. I had no power. I tried to break away for the safety of James and myself. I failed because Peter would not release me. I failed because Peter had too much control over me. I lost all my self respect. My only goal was to get through another day.

story: NewsWoman loses  stone and  dress sizes after being humiliated on holiday from hellAimee Cumbers, , from Maldron, Essex, has shared her tips for keeping the weight off at Christmas - after feeling ashamed over how her weight held her back from enjoying a dream holidayShareCommentsByLouise Lazell:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsAimee Cumbers, from Maldon, has shared her incredible weight loss journey " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Aimee Cumbers, , from Essex, has gone from  stone and a size   to a size . She has slimmed down after realising her -stone frame was holding her back. But her incredible weight loss journey is the result of a huge effort after years of struggles to lose weight. Aimee told Essex Live she had struggled with her weight since she was a little girl, and over the years had tried every diet, shake, juice and trick in the book to try to shed the extra pounds. But it was always the same outcome - lose two stone, then gain more. She described herself as a secret eater. Aimee would buy herself sweets and treats to sneak to her bedroom and eat, hiding the evidence from her parents and lying about itthey found any wrappers. But everything changed after Aimee had a holiday which knocked her confidence to rock-bottom. The turning point was in  when Aimee sat on a plane to go on holiday and nearly couldnapost do her seatbelt up. Coming back from her trip, Aimee decided it was time to make a change. Within a year, she had dropped from a size  to size  after losing over seven stone. Now, she is sharing her story in the hope that she can encourage others to take the leap. Between  and , Aimee became more and more self-conscious about the way she looked after she started getting refused for events because of her weight. The worst memory of this was in Turkey , when she realised her seat belt nearly didnapost fit. She said: It happened a couple of times, I went to Turkey one time and the seat belt was quite tight. I just remember thinkingI get any bigger, I’m going to have to ask for an extension, which made me feel embarrassed as I had never been close to that point before.  No one should feel embarrassed to ask for one, but that’s how I felt personally. It was a turning point. Once Aimee landed, she was excited to do all the events they had planned. She said: Once I got to Turkey, we weaposre going to do all these activities like parasailing and I got refused. They said I had to weigh myself and I was too heavy. They just looked at me and said aposno, sheaposs not going onapos. I felt absolutely mortied. I was so embarrassed. That was it, I was self-conscious the whole time and I couldnapost do anything . My confidence was absolutely gone. It impacted on it in so many dferent ways. But it wasnapost just on holiday where Aimee was refused entry. I wasnapost allowed to do Jump Street. We had a party at work and I couldnapost do it because I was too heavy, she said. I looked online before I went and thought, I canapost go. I told them I couldnapost make it. It was just really upsetting, it was more the embarrassment and not wanting to say thataposs the case. Even just normal activities like shopping and eating out became a source of concern.  Aimee was even worried about going to restaurants to eat in public, in the fear that someone might see her and judge her. Shopping was a major ordeal, I couldnapost just go into Primark and pick up certain things. I had to try it on andI was going away it had to all be a body cover up. I just felt awful. Coming back from her holiday in , Aimeeaposs self-esteem had ebbed to an all time low. When her friends suggested joining Slimming World, she did it thinking it would fail like every other diet she had tried. A few of my friends were going and they said aposcome on Aimee, joinapos. I didnapost have much pressure because I had done it before and it hadnapost worked, she said. I had just got back from holiday and I was feeling bloated and I was looking back at pictures and thinking aposJesus, is that me apos After trying a few Slimming World groups, Aimee found the perfect one. She said: I was in the swing of it. I had support from my boyfriendaposs family and they said I could cook the meals. They were having them with me as well which really helped. My family were so supportive and thats what kept me on. Within a year, Aimee had lost just over seven stone, dropping six dress sizes. She has learnt to cook some amazing meals and met so many new friends at her group sessions. I feel like a dferent woman to the one who walked into Slimming World. It felt really good and to get smaller clothes I started noticing that I could walk into Primark and New Look.  Photographs really helped too. On Instagram you have so many people who are going through the same thing and are all so supportive. With hard work and determination, Aimee has kept the weight off since then, including another ten pounds. One of the toughest times of the year has always been Christmas time, which seems to revolve around food. The first Christmas was really dficult because itaposs just food everywhere and thereaposs temptation everywhere. Itaposs always good to have a day off and not over indulge. I remember the first Christmas I had after I joined Slimming World in October, I had eaten what I wanted. I had all the snacks, chocolate but after a few days I was so poorly. I got to Boxing Day and I was so poorly. Your body isnapost used to it anymore and your stomach has shrunk. I couldnapost believe I used to do that. One of the hardest parts, was the constant encouragement from other people to eat and drinkat Christmas time. It was a lot of pressure, it was all the aposcome on, itaposs Christmas!apos and aposyou have to!apos comments, she said. They didnapost understand it was important I didnapost go back to bad habits. You just canapost help not say: aposeat this, eat thatapos andyou say no it just gets worse. Itaposs a lot of pressure. Itaposs just the run up to Christmas with all the Christmas parties, the sweets, the selection boxes - it just revolves around food.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe festive season is finally upon us and with Christmas parties aplenty, most of us will be making the most of get a bit merry. While it might seem like a wonderful le at the time, the morning after can be a dferent story, thanks to the biggest Grinch of all – a holiday hangover. And with shopping to do, family to see and work to wrap up before the end of the year, thereaposs no time for staying in bed. So, what hangover cures really work  From a full fry-up to hair of the dog, we take a look at what you need to do to make yourself feel better and have a very merry little Christmas... Myth: Have a fry up After a heavy night, itaposs normal to wake up craving carbs – and a greasy fry-up certainly ticks all the boxes. But health experts warn that itaposs best not to bring home the bacon. For, drinking causes you to lose nutrients through urine – and a heavy breakfast could trigger indigestion. As a result, a more nutritious breakfast can help you battle a hangover more quickly. Fruit, such as bananas, can help restore potassium and blood sugar levels. Or,that seems a little too zesty, then honey on toast is also easy for the stomach to digest. Myth: Hit the gym Some people may swear by a sweaty gym class to perk them up after drinking too much – but this can actually do more harm than good, as your body is already dehydrated. Instead, itaposs better to go for a brisk walk in the fresh air to release endorphins and improve circulation, in a gentler way.  Myth: Take a painkiller before bed Think that taking a painkiller before bed will stop any impeding hangover  You couldnapost be more wrong. Most over-the-counter painkillers take  minutes to start working and the results only last a few hours. So, by the time you wake up itaposs likely that you wonapost be able to feel any effects. On top of this, painkillers can mix with the gastric acids created by alcohol in your stomach – which could cause damage to your stomach lining. So,you really need to pop some pills, itaposs best to wait and assess your situation in the morning. Myth: Coffee cures all When youaposre feeling sluggish it can be tempting to reach for the coffee for a bit of a buzz. But although coffee isnapost quite as dehydrating as alcohol, it is still a diuretic and could hinder your recovery. If you really need a caffeine hit, try to stick to just one cup before switching back to water.  Myth: Gorge on late night takeaways Itaposs bad news for those who like to end the night with a burger and chips. For, while it may seem like a good way to soak up excess alcohol, fast food can actually irritate your stomach and cause you to put on weight. Instead, itaposs better to eat a big meal before heading out – to line your stomach before drinking alcohol. Myth: Keep going Continuing to drink may delay your hangover but it certainly wonapost stop it. So, itaposs best to have some water with your breakfast rather than an early-morning beer.

title: boss wants more than wee bursts
story: Dark Blues boss James McPake has challenged his players to develop a real Dundee identity after ending a winless spell of four games.The Dens Park side fell out of the Championship play-off spots after losing three matches in succession.They’ve picked up four points from their last two, however, and James is looking for an extended period of form to get his side back up the league table.Asked how much the bad run of form taught him as a manager, James said: “I learned it’s a lot harder to sleep when you’re not winning!“It’s tough but it’s the same for any manager, experienced or not, losing games and feeling the group isn’t doing the football club justice.“Those three games were poor but we are at the other end now.“We can’t have wee bursts where we are decent, there needs to be a run of performances where you can identy what a Dundee team is.“We can’t wonder whether we are going to turn up – that’s the big thing, consistently performing week in, week out.“Big teams that get out of this league do that and we are striving to do that.”Meanwhile, the Dens gaffer says “watch this space” on the future of -year-old Fin Robertson.The midfielder has made  appearances this season for the first team and James is very keen to extend his current deal beyond its current  end date.“It is something we need to get done,” said James.“He still has two years left on his current deal so there is loads of time. He is one who will be here for a while. We will get it sorted soon.“Fin is in the team because he deserves to play. That’s why he has played the majority of our games this season, it’s because he has been excellent.“He has made  appearances and most of them have been starts. For someone so young, I think he holds his own on the pitch and controls the game at times.“There is a lot to him that’s to like. He gives us a balance. Fin will sit there and break things up.“He has been great for us from day one and is very consistent.“He is going to have a really good career.”
